title.narrative: Mechanism 12933 - Strengthening Private Sector Health Care Services Project (SPSS)

description.narrative:
Additional detail on PEPFAR financial information and terminology can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/financial. The PEPFAR IATI activity file and PEPFAR IATI Activity File User's Guide can be found at https://data.pepfar.gov/additionalData
The goal of this proposed program is to improve the health of the people of Zimbabwe through reduced HIV prevalence among young adults and reduced mortality and morbidity among PLHIV. The strategic objective is to increase the availability of social sector services and related products through the private sector. The program will aim to achieve the following objectives: Expand and improve private Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.15: Biomedical Prevention - Medical Male Circumcision. Policy, training, outreach, message development, service delivery, quality assurance, and equipment and commodities related to male circumcision (MC). Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.6: Adult Care and Support. All facility-based and home/community-based activities for HIV-infected adults and their families aimed at extending and optimizing quality of life for HIV-infected clients and their families throughout the continuum of illness through provision of clinical, psychological, spiritual, social and prevention services. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.11: Treatment/Adult Treatment. Including infrastructure, training clinicians and other providers, exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, and community-adherence activities. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.2: Sexual Prevention - Abstinence/Be Faithful. Activities (including training) to promote abstinence, fidelity, reducing multiple and concurrent partners, and related social and community norms that impact these behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.9: Counseling and Testing. Includes activities in which both HIV counseling and testing are provided for those who seek to know their HIV status (as in traditional VCT) or provider initiated counseling and testing. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.5: Sexual Prevention - Other Sexual Prevention. Other activities (including training) aimed at preventing HIV transmission including purchase and promotion of condoms, STI management (if not in palliative care settings/context), messages/programs to reduce other risks of persons engaged in high-risk behaviors. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.14: Strategic Information. HIV/AIDS behavioral and biological surveillance, facility surveys, monitoring partner results, reporting results, supporting health information systems, assisting countries to establish and/or strengthen such systems, and related analysis and data dissemination activities fall under strategic information. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.7: TB/HIV. Includes exams, clinical monitoring, related laboratory services, treatment and prevention of tuberculosis (including medication), as well as screening and referral of TB clinic clients for HIV testing and clinical care. Funds allocated for Program Element HL.1.13: Health System Strengthening. Include activities that contribute to national, regional or district level systems by supporting finance, leadership and governance (include broad policy reform efforts including stigma, gender, etc.), institutional capacity building, supply chain or procurement systems, Global Fund programs and donor coordination. objectives

The goal of this proposed program is to improve the health of the people of Zimbabwe through reduced HIV prevalence among young adults and reduced mortality and morbidity among PLHIV. The strategic objective is to increase the availability of social sector services and related products through the private sector. The program will aim to achieve the following objectives: Expand and improve private sector based health services; Improve the availability and range of affordable health products or supplies; Promote healthy behaviors. Implementation is at national scale with focus on areas of elevated HIV prevalence - urban areas, growth points, farming areas including resettlement and commercial farms, mining encampments and border towns. Key target groups include adults15-29 years, adolescents (10-19 years) and MARPS (sex workers, internally displaced / mobile populations and PLHIV).The project will rigorously monitor and contain costs. Expansion of new technologies (such as computerization of client intake forms, devices for male circumcision, HIV self- testing) are expected to reduce costs over time and improve efficiencies. Regular reviews of costs for goods and services and its health impact ensure high impact at the lowest cost. The program supports the GOZ HIV National Strategy and uses national M&E indicators. Activities are conducted in collaboration with MOHCC, NAC and ZNFPC, as well as local and community based organizations. M&E will be conducted through: Population-based surveys on: target group behaviors and determinants will be conducted to measure progress and effectiveness of MC communication and demand creation; measuring condom coverage and access; automation of data collection; mystery client survey and quarterly data quality audits.

organisation.narrative: Office of the Global AIDS Coordinator

mailing-address.narrative: 1800 G Street, N.W., Suite 10300, Washington, DC 20006

policy-marker.narrative: The U.S. President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) is the U.S. government's response to the global HIV/AIDS epidemic and represents the largest commitment by any nation to address a single disease in history.

title.narrative: This area of the State Department website contains the standard terms and conditions documents incorporated by reference into all standard grants, cooperative agreements, fixed amount awards, award to individuals, and property awards to U.S. and foreign recipients that are not Foreign Public Entities.
